articles.headline: Arrest Order for Sunni Leader in Iraq Opens New Rift
articles.snippet: The warrant against Vice President Tariq al-Hashimi on terrorism charges was issued on Monday as his party threatened to pull out of the coalition with the Shiite-led government.
articles.abstract: The warrant against Vice President Tariq al-Hashimi on terrorism charges was issued on Monday as his party threatened to pull out of the coalition with the Shiite-led government.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A day after the United States withdrew its last combat troops, Iraq faced a dangerous political crisis Monday as the Shiite-dominated government ordered the arrest of the Sunni vice president, accusing him of running a death squad that assassinated police officers and government officials.

articles.headline: U.S. Backs Apple in Patent Ruling That Hits Google
articles.snippet: The maker of the iPhone won a battle against Google on Monday in a struggle for global cellphone supremacy.
articles.abstract: The maker of the iPhone won a battle against Google on Monday in a struggle for global cellphone supremacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal agency ruled on Monday that a set of important features commonly found in smartphones are protected by an Apple patent, a decision that could force changes in how Google’s Android phones function.

articles.headline: Kim’s Heir Likely to Focus on Stability
articles.snippet: Questions loom about Kim Jong-un’s ability to manage North Korea’s ravaged economy, with its chronic shortages and deprivations, to avoid a complete collapse.
articles.abstract: Questions loom about Kim Jong-un’s ability to manage North Korea’s ravaged economy, with its chronic shortages and deprivations, to avoid a complete collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The death of Kim Jong-il, the hermetic North Korea leader, threw the rest of Asia into deep anxiety Monday and reverberated across the Pacific. Friends and enemies of the nuclear-armed country fretted over whether it was now facing an unpredictable power struggle — even as the official North Korean press proclaimed that Mr. Kim’s cherubic-faced youngest son was his successor.

articles.headline: Cuts for the Already Retired
articles.snippet: If the sharp cuts agreed to by retired police and firefighters in Central Falls, R.I., is approved in court, other places may pursue similar deals.
articles.abstract: If the sharp cuts agreed to by retired police and firefighters in Central Falls, R.I., is approved in court, other places may pursue similar deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Retired police and firefighters from Central Falls, R.I., have agreed to sharp pension cuts, a step thought to be unprecedented in municipal bankruptcy and one that could prompt similar attempts by other distressed governments.

articles.headline: In Kim’s Undetected Death, Sign of Nation’s Opacity
articles.snippet: For South Korean and American intelligence services to have failed to pick up clues right away about Kim Jong-il’s death attests to the secretive nature of North Korea.
articles.abstract: For South Korean and American intelligence services to have failed to pick up clues right away about Kim Jong-il’s death attests to the secretive nature of North Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kim Jong-il, the enigmatic North Korean leader, died on a train at 8:30 a.m. Saturday in his country. Forty-eight hours later, officials in South Korea still did not know anything about it — to say nothing of Washington, where the State Department acknowledged “press reporting” of Mr. Kim’s death well after North Korean state media had already announced it.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Skidding Bank Shares Worry Investors
articles.snippet: Traders are focusing on Europe’s debt problems and the possibility that capital requirements in the United States would also be fortified.
articles.abstract: Traders are focusing on Europe’s debt problems and the possibility that capital requirements in the United States would also be fortified.
articles.lead_paragraph: Talk about a bad anniversary present.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: In Murky Republican Contest, the Clearest Target Is Gingrich
articles.snippet: A furious and sustained barrage of criticism aimed at Newt Gingrich appears to be reshaping the volatile Republican nomination contest once again.
articles.abstract: A furious and sustained barrage of criticism aimed at Newt Gingrich appears to be reshaping the volatile Republican nomination contest once again.
articles.lead_paragraph: A furious and sustained barrage of criticism aimed at Newt Gingrich appears to be reshaping the volatile Republican nomination contest once again with just two weeks left before voters begin weighing in.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Mass March by Cairo Women in Protest Over Abuse by Soldiers
articles.snippet: The demonstration grew by the minute into an extraordinary expression of anger at the treatment of women by the military police.
articles.abstract: The demonstration grew by the minute into an extraordinary expression of anger at the treatment of women by the military police.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Several thousand women demanding the end of military rule marched through downtown Cairo on Tuesday evening in an extraordinary expression of anger over images of soldiers beating, stripping and kicking female demonstrators in Tahrir Square.
